entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Montgomery

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued October 16 at 2:33AM MDT until October 16 at 11:00PM MDT by NWS Riverton WY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Additional snow accumulations of 3 to 6 inches between 7500 and 9000 ft and 5 to 10 inches across higher terrain. 1 to 2 inches expected along South Pass.
* WHERE...Wind River Mountains.
* WHEN...Until 11 PM MDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Winter travel conditions are expected along mountain roads.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Wind River Mountains West; Wind River Mountains East

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 11 PM MDT THIS EVENING

entry.title: Freeze Warning issued October 16 at 2:32AM MDT until October 17 at 9:00AM MDT by NWS Grand Junction CO
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Sub-freezing temperatures as low as 25 expected.
* WHERE...Central Yampa River Basin, Lower Yampa River Basin, Upper Yampa River Basin, Animas River Basin, Four Corners/Upper Dolores River, Paradox Valley/Lower Dolores River, San Juan River Basin, Central Colorado River Basin, and Debeque to Silt Corridor.
* WHEN...From midnight tonight to 9 AM MDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions could kill crops, other sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor plumbing.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lower Yampa River Basin; Central Yampa River Basin; Upper Yampa River Basin; Debeque to Silt Corridor; Central Colorado River Basin; Paradox Valley/Lower Dolores River; Four Corners/Upper Dolores River; Animas River Basin; San Juan River Basin

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 2:30AM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
At 230 AM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over Questa, moving northeast at 55 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and penny size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.
Locations impacted include... Questa, Red River, Taos Ski Valley, Amalia, Arroyo Seco, Arroyo Hondo, Taos Pueblo, Cerro, Lama and San Cristobal.
This includes Highway 64 between Mile Markers 233 and 251.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Upper Rio Grande Valley; Johnson and Bartlett Mesas Including Raton Pass

cap:parameter.value: A STRONG THUNDERSTORM WILL IMPACT NORTHERN TAOS AND NORTHWESTERN COLFAX COUNTIES UNTIL 3 AM MDT

entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued October 16 at 2:32AM EDT until October 17 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Key West FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor saltwater flooding.
* WHERE...Florida Keys.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Minor saltwater flooding of low elevation streets and lots is likely. Some storm drains will overflow, and some seawalls and docks will be overtopped. In the Lower and Middle Keys, minor flooding will be most pronounced around the time of high tide. In the Upper Keys, little relief is expected, even outside the windows of high tide. Boaters can expect less clearance under fixed bridges. Motorists should remember that persistent puddles around the times of high tide are almost certain to contain a mix of saltwater.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Monroe Upper Keys; Monroe Middle Keys; Monroe Lower Keys

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 4:07AM AST until October 16 at 6:30AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Guayanilla, Penuelas and Yauco.
* WHEN...Until 630 AM AST.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous flows over low-water crossings. Water over roadways. River or stream flows are elevated.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 407 AM AST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream flooding. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Guayanilla, PR; Penuelas, PR; Yauco, PR

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 630 AM AST THIS MORNING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 12:51AM PDT by NWS Elko NV
entry.summary:
Patchy fog has developed across portions of Humboldt and northern Lander/Eureka counties this morning. Satellite imagery and remote sensing platforms are depicting patchy fog with visibility dropping to one mile or less in spots. Locations and roads being affected are US Highway 95 from Winnemucca north to Paradise Valley, I-80 from the Humboldt/Pershing county line east to Battle Mountain, and Jungo road from Antelope Summit to Winnemucca. Motorists are urged to use caution when driving along these and other roadways as rapid changes to visibility are likely this morning.
Visit www.weather.gov/elko for the latest weather information.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Humboldt County; Northern Lander County and Northern Eureka County

cap:parameter.value: Patchy fog will continue to impact portions of Humboldt county this morning

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 1:50AM MDT until October 16 at 3:15AM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Arroyo and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...A portion of north central New Mexico, including the following counties, Los Alamos, south central Rio Arriba and northwestern Santa Fe.
* WHEN...Until 315 AM MDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Water over roadways. Overflowing poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 149 AM MDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to training thunderstorms. This will cause arroyo and small stream flooding. Between 1 and 1.5 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.25 to 0.5 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Los Alamos, Espanola, White Rock, Santa Clara Pueblo, Bandelier National Monument, San Ildefonso Pueblo, Hernandez and Chili. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Los Alamos, NM; Rio Arriba, NM; Santa Fe, NM

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 315 AM MDT EARLY THIS MORNING

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued October 16 at 3:47AM EDT until October 17 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, up to 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways. For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents, large breaking waves expected, and strong longshore currents in the surf zone.
* WHERE...Hatteras Island.
* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 8 PM EDT Friday. For the Beach Hazards Statement, from 8 AM EDT this morning through this evening.
* IMPACTS...Up to 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level is possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways resulting in a low threat of property damage. Some roads and low lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns, and homes adjacent to the waterfront will experience shallow flooding. Portions of NC-12 may be impacted with ocean overwash around high tide. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous swimming conditions.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide, which will occur around 10:30 AM Thursday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Hatteras Island

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM EDT FRIDAY... ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT FROM 8 AM EDT THIS MORNING THROUGH THIS EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 12:55AM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary: Patchy dense fog is currently developing over the North-central plains east of the highway 89 corridor. Anyone traveling tonight may encounter highly variable visibility across short distances, falling to as low as a half mile or less. Frost deposition may cause some roads to become slippery, particularly over bridges and overpasses. Slow down and allow extra time to reach your destination if traveling tonight into Thursday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Glacier, Western Toole, and Central Pondera; Eastern Toole and Liberty; Eastern Pondera and Eastern Teton

cap:parameter.value: Patchy dense fog developing over portions of the North- central plains tonight

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 16 at 12:22AM MDT by NWS Rapid City SD
entry.summary: Patchy dense fog can be expected this morning. Motorists should expect rapidly changing visibility, down to near zero at times. Remember to use your low beam headlights in fog, slow down, and provide plenty of braking distance between yourself and any vehicles in front of you.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Ziebach; Haakon; Northern Jackson; Southern Jackson

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued October 15 at 10:31PM PDT until October 16 at 5:00AM PDT by NWS Elko NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations up to 3 inches.
* WHERE...Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range in Elko County.
* WHEN...Until 5 AM PDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Winds will gust as high as 50 mph on exposed ridgetops and near the crest. Travel will be extremely difficult or nearly impossible. Snow covered roads are expected on State Route 229 through Secret Pass, up to Lamoille Canyon, and across Harrison Pass in the southern end of the Ruby Mountains.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 15 at 11:31PM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
Patchy dense fog is currently developing over portions of Central and North-central Montana, mostly for areas along and east of a Great Falls to Havre line.
Anyone traveling tonight may encounter highly variable visibility across short distances as low as a half mile. frost deposition may cause some roads to become slippery, particularly bridges and overpasses. Slow down and allow extra time to reach your destination if traveling tonight into Thursday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Hill County; Northern Blaine County; Western and Central Chouteau County; Bears Paw Mountains and Southern Blaine; Judith Basin County and Judith Gap; Fergus County below 4500ft

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 15 at 9:11PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Astor affecting Volusia and Lake Counties.
.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage due to recent rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The river is forecast to continue a gradual decline within Moderate Flood Stage through late this week and into early next week. However, tide and wind effects could periodically slow the decline.
For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Thursday afternoon at noon EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest to the river on McPherson Lane.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 PM EDT Wednesday the stage was 3.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 PM EDT Wednesday was 3.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 3.2 feet. - Flood stage is 2.3 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 15 at 9:10PM EDT until October 18 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Horry and Marion Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Little Pee Dee River at Galivants Ferry.
* WHEN...Until early Saturday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Flood waters will begin to affect residential yards in the Fork Retch community upstream of Galivants Ferry near the town of Nichols. Swampland flooding becomes noticeable and natural boat landings will be flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:00 PM EDT Wednesday the stage was 9.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this evening to a crest of 9.3 feet early tomorrow afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage Friday evening. - Flood stage is 9.0 feet. - weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Horry, SC; Marion, SC

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY SATURDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued October 15 at 3:42PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
ESFABQ
Rainfall from earlier in the week across northwest New Mexico and southwest Colorado has led to high water levels and substantial flows in the San Juan, La Plata and Animas rivers. Most rivers observed a crest, or peak level, early Wednesday morning with flows slowly starting to slowly decrease and trend down.
However, water levels are still near bankfull within these rivers, and it will be well into Thursday morning before rivers levels drop.
For your safety, stay away from the banks of these rivers. Erosion will make the banks unstable and this fast running water could easily sweep away those distracted near the bank of the river. Avoid any recreational activities on these rivers through Thursday morning.
Expect rises and impacts to nearby roads and low water crossings. Do not drive through water of unknown depth. The road may not be intact below.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Juan, NM

cap:parameter.value: HIGH FLOWS IN THE SAN JUAN, ANIMAS AND LA PLATA RIVERS

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued October 15 at 4:16PM CDT by NWS Brownsville TX
entry.summary:
ESFBRO
The Brownsville Texas National Weather Service Office has implemented Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service (AHPS) for the Los Olmos Creek basin in Deep South Texas. AHPS enables the National Weather Service to provide long-range probabilistic outlooks. This service is also available on the internet.
In the table below...the 90 through 10 percent columns indicate the chance the creek could rise above the listed stage levels in the next 90 days. Example: The Los Olmos Creek near Falfurrias has a flood stage of 11 feet. There is a 50 percent chance the Falfurrias forecast point will rise above 1.7 feet during the next 90 days.
Chance of Exceeding Stages at Specific Locations Valid [10/15/2025 - 01/13/2026]
Location FS(FT) 90% 80% 70% 60% 50% 40% 30% 20% 10% -------- ----- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- Los Olmos Creek Falfurrias 11.0 1.6 1.6 1.6 1.6 1.7 2.3 2.9 3.7 5.9
This long-range probabilistic outlook contains numbers that are calculated using multiple scenarios from 50 years of historical climatological and stream flow data. These numbers also take into account current conditions of the creek and soil moisture. By providing the complete range of probabilistic numbers...the level of risk associated with the long-range planning decisions can be determined.
Additional supportive data and explanation are available on the internet at: http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/long_range.php?wfo=bro
Long range probabilistic outlooks are issued around the third Thursday of every month.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Brooks, TX

cap:parameter.value: Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service (AHPS) long range probabilistic outlook for the Los Olmos Creek basin in Deep South Texas

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued October 15 at 1:03PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
ESFAFC
The Snow Glacier Dammed Lake is releasing. At this time, we do not expect water levels to reach flood stage on the Snow River, but an additional 1 foot rise of water levels is likely through Friday.
As of 12:45PM, the current water level at Cooper Landing is 10.0 feet. Water levels on Kenai Lake and the Upper Kenai River are expected to rise another half foot, cresting on Friday below flood stage.
There is always uncertainty with Glacier Dam Lake releases. Residents living around Kenai Lake should monitor conditions and prepare for rising water levels.
This statement will be updated daily as more information is available.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Skilak Lake; Interior Kenai Peninsula

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 15 at 1:47PM PDT until October 18 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.
* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South Washington Coast.
* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Saturday evening.
* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or drowning.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the water. Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially watchful of children.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Clatsop County Coast; Tillamook County Coast; Central Coast of Oregon; South Washington Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT FROM FRIDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH SATURDAY EVENING

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 15 at 1:43PM PDT until October 18 at 12:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A moderate risk of sneaker waves.
* WHERE...All beaches of Douglas, Coos and Curry Counties.
* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can run up significantly farther on beaches than normal, including over rocks and jetties. These waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the cold ocean waters, resulting in serious injury or death. Waves may also lift driftwood logs, trapping anyone caught underneath.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The risk of sneaker waves will peak during Friday evening, but seas will continue to build through Saturday morning. After brief improvement Saturday night, hazardous conditions due to high surf are possible late Sunday into early Monday.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT FROM FRIDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH SATURDAY MORNING

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued October 15 at 2:20PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
AQAFWD
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an Ozone Action Day for the Dallas-Fort Worth area for Thursday, October 16, 2025.
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone air pollution in the Dallas-Fort Worth area on Thursday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive-through lanes, conserving energy, and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
For more information on ozone:
Ozone: The Facts (www.tceq.texas.gov/goto/ozonefacts)
Air North Texas: (www.airnorthtexas.org)
EPA Air Now (www.airnow.gov/index.cfm?action.local_state&STATEID=45&TAB=0)
Take care of Texas (www.takecareoftexas.org)

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 15 at 1:37PM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
Fine fuels remain very dry across Vermont according to the Vermont Department of Forests, Parks and Recreation. This, combined with gusty northerly winds of 25 to 30 MPH and relative humidity as low as 35%, may have an impact on fire weather conditions. If any fires were to start the weather and fuel conditions could cause fires to quickly get out of control and be difficult to contain.
For more information about the current fire danger rating, any burn restrictions, and wildfire prevention and education, please visit your state forestry or environmental protection website. Remember, a debris burn ban is in effect for all of Vermont which means no open burning of debris is allowed.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Chittenden; Western Addison; Orange; Western Rutland; Eastern Addison; Eastern Rutland; Western Windsor; Eastern Windsor

cap:parameter.value: Fire Weather Concerns Exist Across Western and Central Portions of Vermont on Thursday

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 15 at 1:37PM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
Fine fuels remain very dry across southern and eastern Essex County according to the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. This, combined with relative humidity values as low as 35% and gusty northerly winds of 20 to 30 MPH may have an impact on fire weather conditions Thursday. If any fires were to start the weather and fuel conditions could cause fires to quickly get out of control and be difficult to contain.
For more information about the current fire danger rating, any burn restrictions, and wildfire prevention and education, please visit the New York State forestry or environmental protection website.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Essex; Eastern Essex

cap:parameter.value: Fire Weather Concerns Exist Across Portions of Essex County New York Thursday

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 15 at 10:16AM CDT until October 19 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Aberdeen SD
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Dakota...
James River near Stratford affecting Brown and Spink Counties.
.For sites with a river forecast, the forecast includes precipitation through the next 48 hours. Any future precipitation could affect the forecasts.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...James River near Stratford.
* WHEN...Until Sunday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, Significant amounts of agricultural lands begin flooding.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:45 AM CDT Wednesday the stage was 14.5 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:45 AM CDT Wednesday was 14.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to continue a slow fall below flood stage early Sunday afternoon. - Flood stage is 14.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Brown, SD; Spink, SD

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL SUNDAY EVENING
